metadata.case_name: Manager, M/s. Mohanlal Hargovindas v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant is the Manager of a Bidi manufacturing and labelling factory of M/s. Mohanlal Hargovindas, Jabalpur, engaged in purchase and sale of Bidi in Madhya Pradesh and other states.
In 1951, State of Madhya Pradesh fixed rates of minimum wages payable to workmen engaged in Bidi making manufactories under Minimum Wages Act, 1948.
Rates revised in 1956 by notification dated 23rd February 1956.
New rates notified by MP Government on 30th December 1958, to come into force from 1st January 1959.
Validity of 1958 notification challenged by appellant before MP High Court and successfully struck down.
MP Legislature enacted Minimum Wages (MP Amendment and Validation) Act, 1961 (Act No. 23 of 1961), introducing s.31A into Central Act 11/1948 to validate 1958 notification retrospectively.
Appellant and other Bidi manufacturers challenged 1961 Act under Art.226; High Court allowed petitions, struck down s.31A as invalid on 2nd May 1962.
On 21st June 1962, MP Ordinance No.4 of 1962 passed fixing minimum wages rates retrospectively.
Ordinance replaced by MP Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 (Act No.16 of 1962).
On 5th October 1962, appellant filed application under Arts.226 and 227 challenging validity of Act 16/1962.
MP High Court held Act 16/1962 valid and disallowed application on 5th September 1963.
Appeal preferred to Supreme Court against High Court decision.

legal_issues.text: Whether MP Legislature exercised independent legislative power under Entry 24 List III or merely validated 1958 notification incompetently.
Whether retrospective effect to wages rates imposes unreasonable restrictions on fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f) and (g).
Whether applying ss.20 and 22 of Central Act 11/1948 contravenes Art.20(1).

petitioner_arguments.text: Act No.16/1962 not independent legislation but guise to validate 1958 notification which legislature incompetent to do; s.2 borrows definitions from 1948 Act, s.3 identical rates to 1958 notification.

Retrospective effect from 1 Jan 1959 imposes unreasonable restrictions under Art.19(1)(f)(g) as employers face arrears, closed accounts, distributed profits; liable for compensation under s.20(3) and prosecution under s.22 from past period.
Ss.3 and 4 make past wages payable from 1 Jan 1959, creating liability for offences not in force at time, contravening Art.20(1).

court_reasoning.text: Act is independent legislation fixing rates in Table (identical to 1958); borrowing definitions common practice, not dependent; preamble and s.3 show fixation, not validation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Independent legislation does not cease to be so merely because effect same as validation.

court_reasoning.text: Retrospective operation relevant but not decisive for reasonableness; employers had notice of rates since 1959, expected to provision; hardship imaginary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites Rai Ramkrishna v. State of Bihar for long retrospective validation after judicial strike-down not unreasonable.

court_reasoning.text: S.3 makes rates 'enforceable' from 1 Jan 1959, but payable from 21 Jun 1962 (Ordinance publication) per s.4 proviso to s.20(2); no immediate past liability for compensation/prosecution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No risk of compensation/prosecution for pre-21 Jun 1962 as discretionary and unlikely.

court_reasoning.text: No contravention of Art.20(1) as rates payable only from 21 Jun 1962, not creating ex post facto criminal liability.

holdings.text: MP Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 (Act 16/1962) is valid independent legislation.
Retrospective enforceability from 1 Jan 1959 but payability from 21 Jun 1962 does not impose unreasonable restrictions under Art.19(1)(f)(g).
No violation of Art.20(1) as no ex post facto criminal liability.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rai Ramkrishna v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Retrospective validation after judicial strike-down covering long period not necessarily unreasonable restriction under Art.19(1)(f)(g).

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act, 1948 (Central Act 11 of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied for fixation, revision, claims, enforcement, penalties; s.31A introduced by MP Act.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 (Act 16 of 1962)
statutes_cited.relevance: Fixes minimum wages rates retrospectively enforceable from 1 Jan 1959, payable from 21 Jun 1962.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages (Madhya Pradesh Amendment and Validation) Act, 1961 (MP Act 23 of 1961)
statutes_cited.relevance: Attempted validation of 1958 notification, struck down.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; MP High Court order upheld; MP Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 held valid in its entirety, rejecting all challenges.

key_quotes.text: "Independent legislation does not cease to be so, merely because its effect is the same as it would have been if a validating Act had been passed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument that Act is disguised validation.

key_quotes.text: "Retrospective operation of legislation is a relevant circumstance in deciding its reasonableness... but this is not necessarily a decisive test."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The above provision... is a clear statement of the legislatures intention that it is on the 21st June 1962 that the rates... became payable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Construction resolving payability date, defeating Art.20 and unreasonableness claims.
